Pinjaman yang diterima akan digunakan untuk menambah satu ekor induk lagi. Selain itu untuk membeli pakan ternak babinya yang berupa dedak padi dan dedak gandum (pollard).

loans.use: Membeli bibit Induk - buying piglet.

loans.name: Chhim

texts.en: Mrs. Chhim N., aged 49, is a farmer who earns $1 per day. She is a widow with 4 children, 2 of whom work at a garment factory earning $70 per month each and 2 of whom are students. They rent the stereo equipment in the picture to neighbors for parties and weddings. She would like to borrow $500 to buy pigs to raise extra income for her family.

loans.use: To buy pigs to raise extra income for her family.

loans.name: Leng

texts.en: Mrs. Leng S., aged 44, sells fish at an open air market, which earns her about $3 per day. Her husband, aged 47, is a policeman earning $2 per day. They have seven children. One is employed at a hotel earning $100 per month while two are students. She would like to borrow $500 to purchase fish to raise in her pond to generate additional profit.

loans.use: To purchase fish to raise in her pond to generate additional profit.

loans.name: Sik

texts.en: Mrs. Sik Y., age 29, is a housewife with three children who are students. Her husband, age 33, is a moto-taxi driver and earns $3 per day. She would like to borrow $325 to purchase a passenger cart to attach to her husband's moto-bike so that he can become a tuk-tuk operator and increase their income.

loans.use: Sik would like to purchase a passenger cart to attach to her husband's moto-bike so he can become a tuk-tuk operator.

loans.name: Ros

texts.en: Mrs. Ros Y., age 48, is a widow who sells porridge to earn $4 per day. She has seven children. One is a student, one works at a factory, one works at a casino, and one is an electrician, and three are married and have left home. In order to maximize the growth of her son’s electrician business, she would like to borrow $1000 to purchase electrical tools, including wires and an electric generator, to meet customer demands.

loans.use: Mrs. Ros Ya would like to purchase electrical tools to expand her son’s electrician business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Ni Luh Taman

texts.id:
Ni Luh Taman lives with her husband and 3 children in their modest home, which is made from bamboo walls and zinc roof. Her husband works as a farmer. Bu Luh Taman helps him out at the farm. Even though busy raising her 3 children, she still find time to tend her pigs. Every morning when she is working in the kitchen, her daughter Komang Yuli Astuti helps her. Her pig stile is located not far from her house. Every month she usually gets an extra income of Rp 300.000,00 from the sale of her pigs. She use it to buy household items. She hopes to be able to finance daughter who recently stop schooling due to financial contraints.

Translated from Bahasa by bernard, Kiva volunteer.

Ni Luh Taman tinggal bersama suami dan ketiga orang anaknya di sebuah rumah yang sangat sederhana, beratap genteng dan dinding gedhek bambu. Suaminya bekerja sebagai petani. Bu Luh Taman membantu suaminya bekerja di ladang. Meskipun repot mengurus tiga orang anaknya, dia masih menyempatkan diri mengurus usaha yang sudah di tekuni sejak menikah yaitu beternak babi. Pagi hari sambil mengerjakan pekerjaan di dapur dia dibantu Komang Yuli Astuti - anak gadisnya - mengurus ternak babinya. Babi peliharaannya ditempatkan di kandang sederhana tidak jauh dari belakang rumahnya. Per bulannya dia bisa mendapatkan tambahan pendapatan sebesar Rp 300.000,00 dari hasil penjualan 6 ekor ternak babinya saat ini. Keuntungan yang didapatkan digunakan membeli bahan-bahan untuk fondasi rumah, karena mereka ingin memilki sebuah rumah yang lebih bagus dari sebelumnya. Harapannya usaha ini juga akan dapat membiayai anak gadisnya yg telah putus sekolah SD karena tidak memiliki biaya.

loans.use: Membeli bibit dan pakan - Buying piglets and feedings

loans.name: Much

texts.en: Mrs. Much S., age 28, sells grocery products at a local market to earn $7 per day. Her husband, age 32, is an electrician who earns $7 per day. They have two children, one of whom is a student. She would like to borrow $1000 to purchase rice and animal feed to increase the variety of products in her inventory and increase profits.

loans.use: Much would like to purchase rice and animal feed to increase her inventory.

loans.name: Ranohon

texts.ru:
Ranohon is a heroic mother—she raised 7 children. The older ones already have they own families. Ranohon is an energetic woman that cannot sit idle, so she sells food products on a market. To buy her products, Ranohon travels 100 km from her home. Ranohon has been an active MicroInvest client for 2 years. The money she received from MicroInvest, helped Ranohon to develop and expand her business.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

По нынешним временам Ранохон можно назвать матерью героиней, так как у нее 7 детей. Старшие ее дети уже имеют свои семьи. Ранохон не может сидеть без дела и поэтому она выходит на базар торговать. Ассортимент ее товаров составляет продукты питания. За товаром она ездит за 100 км от ее дома. С Микроинвест она сотрудничает уже 2 года и является одной из активных клиенток. Получаемые займы способствуют развитию ее бизнеса в положительную сторону.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Rokiahon

texts.ru:
When she found out about MicroInvest, Rokiahon decided to takeout a loan to purchase fruits. Using the loan she purchased fresh grapes and pomegranates. This gave her the opportunity to earn a respectable profit. Rokiahon is 40 years old, is married and is raising 5 children. Profits from her business allow Rokiahon to cover most of the family’s expenses.

Rokiahon plans to take out a new loan for $1200 and to pay it back over 12 months. She will use the new loan to purchase grapes.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

Узнав о Микроинвест, Рокияхон решила получить займ на закупку фруктов. На полученный займ она закупила свежий виноград и гранаты. Это дало возможность получить приличный доход. Рокияхон 40 лет, она замужем и воспитывает 5 детей. Доходы от бизнеса позволяют ей покрывать большинство семейных расходов. Рокияхон планирует получить новый займ в $1200 и погашать его в течении 12 месяцев. Новый займ она потратит на закупку винограда. .

loans.use: for expansion of business

loans.name: Sahoba

texts.ru:
Sahoba sells fresh fruits. She started in the business several years ago. Her products include apples, pears, figs, pomegranates, etc. She purchases the fruits wholesale and sells them at retail. Sahoba is 32 years old and she is raising 2 children. Her husband works here and there at several jobs. The profits from the business comprise their family earnings.

Recently Sahoba received a loan from MicroInvest to expand her business. She plans to use the new loan to further expand her business.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

Сахоба продает свежие фрукты. Бизнесом стала заниматься несколько лет назад. Ассортимент ее товаров включает в себя яблоки, груши, инжир, гранаты и т.п. Она покупает фрукты оптом и реализует их в розницу. Сахобе 32 года и она воспитывает двоих детей. Ее муж подрабатывает на разных работах. Полученные доходы являются их семейным доходом. Недавно Сахоба получила займ в Микроинвест на расширение своего бизнеса. Она планирует получить новый займ на дальнейшее расширение своего бизнеса.

loans.use: for expansion of business

loans.name: Mashhura

texts.ru:
Mashhura is a young woman who is 27 years old. She is not married and lives with her parents. In order to help her parents she sells greens and vegetables at the market. She has been getting loans from MicroInvest for a year now. The purpose of the loans is to increase her inventory. Mashhura plans to use the new loan to purchase vegetables and to can/preserve them.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

Машхура молодая девушка 27 лет. Она незамужем и живет с родителями. Чтобы помочь своим родителям она выходит торговать на рынок. Она продает зелень и овощи. В Микроинвест она получает займы уже в течении года. цель займов – увеличение товарооборота. Сейчас она хочет получить новый займ на закупку овощей и их консервирование.

loans.use: to expand business

loans.name: Umriniso

texts.ru:
Umriniso is the mother of 5 children and is 41 years old. Her husband is earning money in Russia and sends money to support the family. Umriniso sells greens and canned vegetables at the market. The profits from the business add to the family income. She has been working with MicroInvest for a year. The loans have had a positive effect on her business.

Umriniso plans to use the new loan to further expand her business.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

Умринисо мать пятерых детей и ей 41 год. Ее муж находится на заработках в России и присылает денег на содержание семьи. Сама Умринисо продает зелень и консервированные овощи на рынке. Доход от бизнеса является прибавкой к семейному доходу. С Микроинвест она сотрудничает уже год. Полученные займы положительно сказываются на течении ее бизнеса. Она собирается получить новый займ на дальнейшее расширение своего бизнеса.

loans.use: to expand business

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en:
Mohamad, 60, married and father of 6 children, owns a small business making OrientA. pastries and other sweets. Mohamad has been working in this domain since the age of 16, after he learned the recipes and pastry-making secrets from his relatives.

Mohamad has been a client of A. Majmoua for the past 5 years and it is a pleasure to be in a business relation with such a hardworking and gentle man. Mohamad is the type of person who always looks at the cup that is half full (not half empty!) and tries to make his best of life every day for the sake of his large family.

Mohamad needs a loan of US$ 1,200 to buy flour, sugar, and other basic products to prepare large quantities of sweets that he will sell during the coming holiday season. Indeed, the end of the year is usually the high season for Mohamad's business.

loans.use: Purchase flour, sugar and other basic products to prepare a large quantity of pastries and sweets

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en:
Mohamad, 57 years old, married and father of 4 children, owns a small butcher shop in Tripoli, in the north of Lebanon.

Mohamad has been a client of A. Majmoua for the past 3 years and has a very good record of on-time repayments. He needs a loan of US$ 1,200 to replace one of his meat choppers and repair his fridge.

loans.use: Repair the fridge and replace one of the meat choppers in his butcher shop

loans.name: Yosr

texts.en:
Yosr, 52 years old, married and mother of 3 children, has a small dressmaking shop in the area of Ras Al Nabeh in Beirut. Yosr is an excellent business woman and a very professional seamstress who makes evening and wedding dresses, but also sportswear designs and does clothes repairs upon request.

When we first met her, Yosr was working alone from a small room underground. With the 7 consecutive loans she has borrowed from Al Majmoua, she has been able to quit this "squalid" place, rent a large atelier on the 1st floor of a much nicer building, buy some new sewing machines, and recruit 3 seamstresses. She has kept expanding her base of clients till a point where 24 hours a day is not enough for her to answer all the requests she receives.

Yosr plans to keep expanding her business till she feels she is financially secure and able to cover the university expenses of her children. Yosr now needs a loan in the amount of US$ 1,200 to purchase fabrics, threads and other accessories.

loans.use: purchase fabrics, threads and other accessories

loans.name: Rola

texts.en:
Rola, 27 years old, married and mother of 2 children, is a seamstress who lives in the area of Al Rwaissat in Beirut. Before knowing about Al Majmoua, she was employed in a small atelier and was being paid very little by the owner. She heard about our Institution from word of mouth and applied for a loan to purchase a sewing machine. Her loan was approved, she bought the machine, quit her job and opened a business on her own.

This is the 3rd time Rola is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua. This time, she needs a loan of US$ 600 to buy a new sewing machine. Rola is part of a group loan with other women from the same neighborhood. They named their group "Iya," that means "She". A group is usually constituted of self-chosen women, living in vulnerable conditions. The group lending is based on incremental increase of the loan amount and group solidarity to guarantee repayment. The strength of the group loan is that it encourages the collaboration approach in the borrowing community; it is a very powerful tool towards the economic empowerment of women.

loans.use: Purchase of a new sewing machine

loans.name: Majida

texts.en:
Majida, 41 years old, married and mother of 5 children, runs a small business from home in the area of Al Rwaissat in Beirut. She buys home products, small appliances, and accessories and sells them back in her neighborhood.

Two years ago, Majida heard about our Institution from word of mouth and applied for a loan to purchase more inventory. This is the 3rd time Majida is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua. This time, again, she needs a loan of US$ 600 to buy home products. Her dream is to open a small shop of her own in an area near her home to have better visibility for her business.

Majida is part of a group loan with other women from the same neighborhood. A group is usually constituted of self-chosen women, living in vulnerable conditions. The group lending is based on incremental increase of loan amount and group solidarity to guarantee repayment. The strength of the group loan is that it encourages the collaboration approach in the borrowing community; it is a very powerful tool towards economic empowerment of women.

loans.use: Purchase of a stock of home products, small appliances, and accessories for resale

loans.name: Llane

texts.en:
From the time she was a little girl, Llane learned to sell fruits next to her dear mother who, with her ability and gentle touch, taught her daughter diligence and patience. She is now the mother of two school-age children. With her sister's assistance in selling her products, and her husband's help with the household expenses, she buys and sells fruits, corn and beans around the small farms lining the Federico Basadre highway in her hometown. In this form she tries to generate additional income to improve her family's quality of life.

During this entire time, she has been saving money with the goal of buying a small space to sell her products, but her savings are not quite enough. For this reason, she's requesting a loan in the amount of $200, which she will repay over a period of six months.

Translated from Spanish by Rosario McFaull, Kiva Volunteer.

Llane desde muy pequeña aprendió y desempeño la actividad de venta de frutas a lado de su querida mamá, quién gracias a su habilidad y buen trato inculcó en ella mucha diligencia y paciencia. Ahora es madre de dos hijos que aún se encuentran en etapa escolar; mientras recibe el apoyo de su hermana en la venta y la colaboración de su esposo para satisfacer los gastos que genera diariamente su hogar se dedica a la compra y venta de granos de maíz y frejol por las tierras de cultivo que se encuentran en los márgenes de la carretera Federico Basadre de su ciudad. De esta manera trata de generar un ingreso adicional para incrementar la calidad de vida de su familia. Durante todo este tiempo ha estado ahorrando con el propósito de adquirir un espacio propio de ventas en el mercado, sin embargo aún el dinero con el que cuenta es insuficiente para concretar la compra; por esa razón solicita un préstamo de 200 dólares con el propósito de alcanzar sus objetivos motivo por el cual ella ha puesto en nosotros todas sus esperanzas y se compromete a devolver lo solicitado en un periodo de seis meses.

loans.use: To buy more inventory to increase her sales and save enough to open her own retail space.

loans.name: Liz Maritza

texts.es:
Liz began the poultry sales business as a result of one of her sisters giving up a space in ” the Hoyada” market (in her city), which was designated for this purpose. She has two small children who attend school. Her husband has recently had to leave home in order to find work to help supplement their income, and sends them money whenever he can.

Liz begins working very early each morning and also utilizes the services of a taxi to bring in additional income. Since the market space she uses, isn't hers and she has to pay rent, Liz has to figure out a way to offer more products in order to make good sales and bring in more money. It is for this purpose that Liz is requesting a loan of $925 USD, with the promise of repaying it within 6 months. With hope of getting a quick response, she puts all her hope in us.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Gould, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Liz empezó con la venta de los pollos a raíz de que una de sus hermanas le cedió un espacio para este propósito en el mercado ” La Hoyada” de su ciudad, ella vive con dos pequeños que se encuentran en etapa escolar, su esposo hace poco tiempo ha tenido que ausentarse de su lado por motivos de trabajo y desde su lugar de residencia trata de procurarles bienestar a los miembros de su familia. Su actividad comercial inicia desde muy temprano por la mañana vendiendo pollos y también cuenta con un mototaxi que brinda servicios de transporte urbano que le genera un ingreso adicional. Como el puesto en el que trabaja no es propio necesita aumentar las ventas para poder completar el costo del mismo y adquirirlo. Por esta razón solicita un préstamo de 925 dólares con el compromiso de devolverlos en un período no mayor a seis meses y con la esperanza de encontrar pronta respuesta deposita todas sus esperanzas en nosotros.

loans.use: To buy more poultry in order to increase her sales and grow her business.

loans.name: Manuela

texts.es:
Manuela and her husband have four daughters - 2 are in grade school, one is about to complete her university degree online, and the 4th is attending university locally. In order to supplement their income, they have turned a strategic section of their backyard into a small general store where they sell important household items. In order to stock her store, Manuela often travels to her country's capital, where she purchases a variety of items at good prices. While she travels she depends on her daughters' help running the shop and on the help of her husband who takes on independent side jobs, which is necessary to supplement their expenses and help pay their daughters' educational expenses.

Manuela is requesting a loan of $1,200 USD in order to purchase home decoratives and clothing in order to supplement the products she currently sells in her store. She is planning to repay this loan within 6 months. Together we can quickly make her dreams a reality.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Gould, Kiva volunteer.

Manuela y su esposo tienen 4 hijas, dos de ellas aún en etapa escolar, la mayor a punto de culminar sus estudios universitarios exitosamente y la segunda en continuas horas de estudio también en las aulas universitarias de su ciudad. Actualmente como sostén del hogar cuentan con una pequeña tienda de venta de artículos de primera necesidad, ubicada en un lugar estratégico en el patio de su casa.Para mantener muy bien equipado y acondicionado este espacio viajan constantemente a la capital de su país con el objeto de traer mayor variedad y cantidad de productos para ofrecerlos a menor costo, cuenta con el apoyo de dos de sus hijas en la bodega mientras esta ausente y adicionalmente también recibe el aporte de su esposo que realiza trabajos en forma independiente para satisfacer exitosamente las necesidades de su hogar y la educación de sus hijas. El próximo objetivo de Manuela es incrementar sus servicios y productos con la venta de ropas y adornos para el hogar. Debido a ello solicita un préstamo de 1200 dólares con el compromiso de retornarlos en un lapso de 6 meses. Juntos podemos lograr la cristalización de sus anhelos en poco tiempo.

loans.use: Loan will be used to purchase home decorative items and clothing to sell in her store, which will help grow their business.

loans.name: Meredith De Jesús

texts.es:
Meredtih is a young mother of two small children. She is separated temporarily from her husband because his labor obligations take him out of their city in order to find work to meet their financial needs and responsibilities. During one of their difficult times, with the help of her eldest daughter, she decided to embark on making juices in her home and to sell them in the city market. At first it was difficult because she didn't expect how hard it would be to store the prepared juice, since she didn't have the proper space. Later, and with much effort, Meredith managed to rent a space in the nearby market and in just a short time, things began to improve considerably. Now, due to the increasing demand for her juices, Meredith has decided to acquire more utensils and associated juicing merchandise in order to improve service. For this reason, she is asking for a loan of $500 USD, which she plans to repay in a short period of time (6 months).

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Gould, Kiva volunteer.

Meredtih es una joven madre de dos pequeños niños; se encuentran separados temporalmente del jefe de familia debido a que sus obligaciones laborales las tiene que desempeñar fuera de su ciudad natal sin descuidar ni dejar de contribuir con los gastos de su hogar La falta de trabajo hizo que se dedicara a la venta de jugos con el apoyo de su hija mayor en el mercado de su ciudad con el objetivo de procurarles bienestar e incrementar la calidad de vida de los mismos.Al principio fue una difícil tarea por que no contaba con el espacio ni el lugar idóneo para ofrecer sus preparados, posteriormente y con mucho esfuerzo logró alquilar un espacio en el mercado más concurrido y en poco tiempo las cosas han ido mejorando notablemente. Debido a la demanda creciente de su trabajo ha decidido adquirir más utensilios y artefactos con el propósito de mejorar su servicio a razón de este hecho solicita el préstamo de 500 dólares con el deseo de concretar en corto tiempo sus metas..

loans.use: To purchase utensils and items for her juicing business.

loans.name: Juana Lucía

texts.es:
Juana began working at the age of 12, by helping her mother run a small store located within their home. Now she runs a store which she built with the help of her family.

Juana is married and has 7 children - 3 of them attend university and help around the store during their free time - the other 4 are on their own running their own families. Juana's husband is retired from the education sector and in order to supplement his very low monthly pension, he offers tuturing services to grade school children, which he provides by working from home.

Juana and her husband would now like to expand their small store to include her husband's services and provide academic services to children from grade school through their university years. This would enable them to provide better services to meet the needs of their community. They are therefore requesting a $400 USD loan, which they'll repay in 6 months.

Thanks for the help you can offer, they'll be able to turn their dream into reality within a short time.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Gould, Kiva volunteer.

Juana empezó a trabajar desde los doce años; en principio como compañía de su madre en una modesta bodega instalada en un pequeño espacio de su hogar y ahora en una que construyó con ayuda de su familia. Es madre de siete hijos; tres de ellos están en la universidad y apoyan en sus horas libres con la administración de la bodega; los otros cuatro ya no se encuentran al amparo de ella debido a que ahora velan por el bienestar de sus propias familias. Su esposo es jubilado del sector educativo. Quién debido a la insuficiente suma de dinero que percibe mensualmente ofrece asesoría educativa en las instalaciones de su hogar a pequeños en etapa escolar. Desde muy temprano empieza ofreciendo sus servicios a la comunidad y su próximo deseo es ayudarlos a concluir satisfactoriamente sus carreras universitarias. Con el propósito de evitar algún imprevisto en el normal desarrollo de sus tareas desea ampliar las instalaciones de su bodeguita para ofrecerles mayor variedad de productos y servicios, por esta razón solicita un préstamo de 400 dólares financiado en seis meses. Gracias al apoyo que puedas otorgarle en corto tiempo podrá convertir sus anhelos en realidad

loans.use: Loan will be used to improve their store to include academic/ educational services and consulting, in order to grow their business and for the well-being of their community's families.

loans.name: Vilma

texts.es:
Vilma has been selling fruit at the market here since 1982. She has a daughter pursuing a university degree and shares a humble dwelling with her husband. The couple works together starting at 5:00 AM selling fruit at a stall they rent at the market. Vilma's husband takes care of buying the fruit, which comes from the interior, at the port, while Vilma tends to the stall. They have long labored in hopes of obtaining their own stall where they can better keep and display the produce. To this end they are asking for a loan of $275 which they promise to repay in six months. This will go to paying the last installment on the purchase of a stall so they can better tend to their customers.

Translated by a Kiva volunteer.

Vilma empezó a vender en el mercado desde el año 1982; es madre de una hija que cursa estudios superiores en la universidad de su ciudad y habita una humilde morada en compañía de su esposo. Ambos trabajan desde las cinco de la mañana en el espacio que alquilaron en el mercado para vender frutas producidas en el interior de su país, su esposo se encarga de hacer las compras en el puerto regional con el propósito de ofrecer mayor variedad de productos a menor costo y también se encarga del traslado de las frutas al mercado mientras Vilma sigue atendiendo la demanda de sus clientes. A través del tiempo han ido desempeñando sus labores con el deseo de adquirir un espacio propio para acondicionarlo debidamente con el objetivo de mantener sus productos mejor distribuidos y preservados. Para alcanzar su meta necesitan el financiamiento de 275 dólares con un plazo de seis meses de devolución este capital le permitirá completar el pago del espacio e irá iniciando los trabajos para ofrecer un mejor servicio a sus clientes.

loans.use: To stock a fruit stand in hopes of someday being able to own it.

loans.name: Pura

texts.en:
Pura works hard to support 6 people in her family. She raises and sells pigs to local community members, but recently spent a lot of money on a pig that became sick and died. She is requesting this small loan so that she will be able to buy plantains from local Haitian workers to sell to her community members. With this loan she hopes that she can begin to regain some of the money she lost when her pig died, and eventually get back on her feet again with her business.

Pura's dream is to one day build a home out of concrete blocks, with a concrete roof and floor, and to also have a separate room where she can prepare the pork that she sells to her neighbors.

NOTE: Pura is one of five microentrepreneurs in her Unidos Podemos (United We Are Able) Bank of Hope solidarity group. They have all gone through Esperanza's business training courses and will be accountable to each other for repaying $60 each of this $300 loan together. This group-lending method strengthens social needs in a community and ensures that members cooperate to help one another repay their loans and invest wisely in their business and family.

loans.use: Purchase plantains for resale

loans.name: Francisca

texts.en:
Francisca is a young mother, doing her best to provide a healthy and happy life for her husband and two children. As with most families in her neighborhood, her husband has a hard time finding consistent work in the off-season for sugar cane, and so Francisca works hard to make up the difference. She is requesting this loan to purchase chickens to prepare and sell in her community.

Francisca is very involved with the local Club de Madres, or Mothers' Club, and her Catholic church. Her goal is to continue expanding her business so that she is able to own and sell more chickens to her community members. She says that she sends her children to a good school so that they can hopefully have a better future than her, but the school costs 60 pesos a day, per child. She is very thankful for this loan because she knows that it will give her a chance to pay for her children’s education, as well as earning enough to supply food, clothes, and shelter.

loans.use: Purchase chickens to prepare and sell

loans.name: Agueda

texts.es:
Águeda is the mother of four. Two of her children are still in school, while the two eldest have already moved away and have their own families. Her husband works in an local factory. Águeda works full-time as a seamstress. She also tends a small shop in her home selling household items. With the income from this stand and her husband's support she has saved up enough to buy a professional-grade sewing machine. At this time, she wants to outfit a workshop in her home and acquire another machine so she can ramp up her production of underwear. She is asking for a loan of $325 to see her dreams become a reality. Please help this hard-working woman and her family.

Translated by a Kiva volunteer.

Águeda es madre de 4 hijos, dos de ellos estudian en el colegio y los dos mayores se han independizado hace poco para vivir fuera de su ciudad natal en compañía de sus respectivas familias. Su esposo se desempeña como obrero en un fábrica industrial de su ciudad con el propósito de incrementar los ingresos familiares para la satisfacción plena de la demanda de su hogar.Siempre ha desempeñado su labor de confección de prendas de vestir a tiempo completo.Inicialmente halló en la venta de artículos de primera necesidad una importante fuente para generar ingresos adicionales fue así que instaló en una mesita del patio de su casa su pequeño espacio de ventas y poco a poco con el transcurrir del tiempo reunió lo suficiente para acondicionarlo en un espacio más amplio de su casa y con el apoyo de su esposo decidió adquirir una máquina de coser profesional para el buen desempeño de su labor. Actualmente su meta es mejorar las instalaciones de su bodega y adquirir una máquina recubridora, con los réditos que genere, para la elaboración de prendas interiores en menor tiempo. Su solicitud es por un monto de 325 dólares con el podrá llevar a cabo sus planes y en corto tiempo sus sueños se verán cristalizados. Brindémosle nuestro apoyo desinteresado y generoso a esta madre ejemplo de nobleza y trabajo.

loans.use: To supply a general store and outfit a garment shop.

loans.name: Justa

texts.en:
Justa has applied for this loan because she plans to purchase chicken, ice, and gasoline, which she sells from her house to her community called Margarita in the province of El Seybo. Justa is very careful with her money and keeps a record of what she buys and sells, her income and expenses, in a notebook. She is responsible for providing for 9 people in her house; her husband is not able to maintain a consistent source of income or work.

In addition to having to provide for so many people, she has to live with a severe case of anemia. About two years ago she had to stop working entirely because she was so ill. Now she feels better, but gets tired often.

NOTE: Justa is one of four microentrepreneurs in her Bank of Hope solidarity group whose businesses will be funded by this loan. They have all gone through Esperanza's business training courses conducted by their Esperanza loan advisor, Algenis Chevalier. Each of the four members will receive a share of this $1,200 loan for their respective businesses and will be accountable to each other for repaying their share of this loan together. This group-lending method strengthens social needs in a community and ensures that members cooperate to help one another repay their loans and invest wisely in their business and family.

Justa estimates she makes about US$ 9-15 a week from her business and always puts part of her income away for savings, using the other part to reinvest into the business and try to diversify her products more. Her goal is to continue improving and advancing, that way she can help her family have more to eat, a better education, and so that they can own their own house built out of concrete blocks. Justa is very grateful for the chance to achieve a better future for her family. She says that these loans can help her get there, one step at a time.

loans.use: Purchase chicken, gasoline, filtered water for resale

loans.name: Martire

texts.en:
Martire runs her colmadito (small neighborhood grocery store) by herself and is asking for her fourth loan to expand her inventory. She is very responsible with her income and savings and keeps a record of her expenses, sales, and inventory in a notebook she carries everywhere with her. With her past loans, she has managed to use her savings to buy a freezer. She says her ability to purchase this freezer has been the key to her success. She is now able to sell perishable items, cold water, and cold beer to her neighbors—and as a result has greatly increased her sales.

Martire says it has been a hard life; she supports her three children, her mother who is very ill, and her husband by herself. She is grateful, however, that one step at a time, she has been able to improve her income and the welfare of her family members. Martire is very involved with her Catholic Church, and the local Club de Madres (Mothers' Club). She is most grateful for these loans and believes that they have truly changed her life for the better.

loans.use: Expand inventory with vegetables, fruit, beverages, canned food, bread, etc.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria is on her fifth loan from Esperanza. She sells chickens to entrepreneurs like herself for their businesses. People from nearby communities come to Maria to buy her chickens, and they in turn sell them in their own communities. Maria estimates that she sells an average of 300-400 pesos' worth of chicken in a day (US$ 9-12). She has three staff: her husband, herself, and her son are in charge of running the business each day. She supports six people in her household on a daily basis—herself, her husband, her son, and her 3 grandsons.

NOTE: This is a group loan. The $1,200 will fund Maria's business plus 4 others in her community. She and four other entrepreneurs have formed a solidarity group that received business training from Esperanza and guarantee each other's loan repayment. This group-lending methodology fosters accountability among the members because they all must pay in full and on time.

Maria is very thankful for the loans from Esperanza and hopes to continue taking them out as long as she can. Before she had her loans, she had to depend on her husband’s earnings, which were not stable. She is now very proud that she maintains a constant source of income, and that she has been able to expand her business with each loan. Just this week she bought a pig for 8,000 RD pesos (about US$ 240) with savings from her and her husband’s income—without the loans they would never have had the savings to invest in a pig. She hopes one day to build a home out of concrete blocks, and a cement roof; her house right now is made from wood with a corrugated zinc roof; she worries that if a hurricane comes her house will be destroyed.

Maria is a savvy micro-entrepeneur. She explains that with the income she earns from the loans, she is careful to both save and re-invest her money. Buying a pig with her savings will allow her to earn more money in the next year from the pork she is able to sell. Once she begins to earn more money from her pig, she will begin saving so that she can build a better and safer house for her family. Maria is most thankful that she has had the blessing of these loans and is grateful that she is being given the opportunity to take out another one.

loans.use: Purchase chickens for resale

loans.name: Lidia

texts.en:
Lidia is asking for her third loan. She has sold gasoline and ice cream in the past, but now wants to invest in a small colmadito next year ( a colmadito is a local grocery store). She says it is very hard to make a good living in her community from gasoline or ice cream; there are very few people who have enough money to own a personal moto, and no buses ever pass through her community. Additionally, it is expensive to keep a freezer, and often costs more than her sales from ice cream can cover. Nevertheless, she has always managed her money carefully and made all of her payments on time. She supports six people in her house, including herself.

NOTE: This is a group loan. Lidia and her business represent the four other members of her group, who each will receive a share of this $750 loan to fund their respective businesses. As members of a solidarity group, Lidia and the other four micro-entrepreneurs have gone through Esperanza´s business training courses and have proven to be committed to their businesses to provide for their families. If a member of the group is unable to make a payment, the other members are responsible for making up the difference and helping the person to improve. This group-lending method creates a social support network within the community as well as an accountability system to ensure that not only are loans paid back on time, but that the loan capital is invested in developing their business and providing for the basic necessities of their families.

Lidia is very involved in her neighborhood and believes that the loans have helped her not only improve the livelihood of her family, but have also allowed her a little extra free time to integrate more with her community so that she can give back to those who need her help. Lidia is very grateful for the opportunities she has been given, is proud of what she has accomplished, and is very optimistic that she can continue improving her future with the help from the micro-loans she receives.

loans.use: Purchase gasoline, ice cream, and supplies to start a grocery store

loans.name: Dolores

texts.en:
Dolores estimates that she sells an average of 300-400 RD pesos of chicken each day (US$ 9-12); she is the sole person in charge of her business. She hopes that with the earnings and savings she can generate with this loan she will one day be able to buy several cows so that she can sell milk for cheese and candies. Her community is known for the cheeses and candies that it makes, so she thinks that would be a great business opportunity. She plans to get there by steadily re-investing her earnings into more chickens first, and then, as her sales increase, into a cow. Dolores is very involved with her local church and community. She is thankful for the opportunities and hope this loan will give her.

NOTE: This is a group loan. Dolores is a member of an Esperanza solidarity group. She and her business represent four other micro-entrepreneurs who are members of the same solidarity group. Each members will receive a share of this $1,200 loan to develop their respective businesses. Payments are made together at biweekly meetings. If one person is unable to pay, the other members must make up the difference before any payment will be accepted. The group has gone through Esperanza´s business training courses and have demonstrated their commitment and aptitude for receiving a loan to expand their businesses. Dolores and the other members are also responsible for working with one another as a social support network throughout the loan repayment period and business development processes.

loans.use: Expand inventory of chicken

loans.name: Luz Yolanda

texts.es:
Luz is a diligent woman whom throughout her life has always been able to take on and overcome obstacles in her day to day activities. Her strength of character has brought her many rewards. A while back Luz began a business selling fuel from a pump located in the main highway of her country. Her dream of becoming a successful business owner however has already been shaken on two separate occasions because the people with whom she tried to forge her dreams abandoned her while she was pregnant. This affected her deeply, nevertheless, thanks to her abilities as a strong woman she has continued on full-speed ahead and will not allow herself to be brought down by adversities. She sees in her daughters the meaning and importance of life. They give her the strength she needs to keep going and reach her goals. Luz has started selling fuel again, but the high price of the leasing of the space takes up most of her earnings. It is for this reason that she asks for a sum of 325 dollars in order to begin the construction of her own space in which she can sell her fuel and a small house in the same place so that she can administer her establishment directly. Please help contribute to Luz so that she can have a comfortable place to develop her business with the strength of character for which she is so well known.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca, Kiva Volunteer.

Luz es una diligente señora que a lo largo de su vida siempre manifestó un inmenso deseo de superación y laboriosidad en cada una de las actividades que ha emprendido; debido a la fuerza de su carácter ha cosechado muchas satisfacciones. Hace tiempo emprendió el negocio de la venta de combustibles en un grifo ubicado en la carretera central de su país; pero este sueño se ha visto ya frustrado hasta en dos oportunidades porque las personas con las que intentó forjar estos deseos, la abandonaron dejándola sola y con un hijo de por medio, este hecho la afectó mucho sin embargo su fortaleza femenina la ha mantenido en pie y con más fuerzas para no decaer y tampoco dejarse vencer por las adversidades; ha visto en sus hijas la razón e importante motor de su vida para perseverar y alcanzar sus objetivos, de manera que ha iniciado una vez más la venta de combustible, pero el alto precio del arriendo de este espacio, hace que el mayor porcentaje de ganancias se utilicen para el pagodel mismo; motivo por el cual solicita la suma de 325 dólares con el propósito de comenzar la construcción de un espacio propio para la venta de combustible y una pequeña vivienda en el mismo lugar de manera que pueda administrar directamente su establecimiento. Colaboremos para que Luz pueda tener un recinto cómodo para desarrollar sus actividades con el empeño y fuerza que la caracteriza.

loans.use: Contruction of her own store in order to sell fuel under safer conditions

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria is 43 years old and has four children, including a daughter who has a child of her own. She also takes care of her niece, because her sister left the child with her when she went to the States. Her husband left her, so she is the sole provider for her household but her children and her mother help her run her store.

Maria runs a small grocery store selling essential foods such as rice, fruit, and vegetables. She also sells over-the-counter medicines, which she buys from a pharmacy in in the capital, Santo Domingo. She is a continuing client. With her profits so far, she has been able to purchase wood to repair her house, instead of tin. This loan will go to expand her inventory.

Maria is the president of a local “mothers’ club”, a group of 36 women who are involved in various things in the community, including trying to build a school in her area of Los Alcarrizos.

loans.use: Purchase staples as well as medicine for her store

loans.name: Marie

texts.en:
Marie is requesting $1,500 USD from Esperanza and her house is her guarantee. She is the sole recipient of her loan; she does not have a group. She is a new client. Previously she had taken out a loan from a bank in town, but the interest was enormous. The loan was $2,125 USD but with interest, she had to pay back $3,850 (so the interest was more than 80%).

Marie has a small clothing store next to her house which she runs with her husband, Jonas Fontaine. She wants to expand her business by putting a small restaurant in front of her shop. Her son sells hot dogs on the street and she wants to buy a machine so they can make them themselves and sell them in the restaurant.

Marie is 53 and has six children. Her youngest is 16 years old and they are all going to school (Marie only has a basic education). She’s from Haiti which borders the Dominican Republic to the west but has lived in the DR for 14 years. She speaks Creole and Spanish.

loans.use: Purchase building materials, food and equipment to create a restaurant

loans.name: Sofía

texts.en:
Sofía V. Guarachi, married and a mother of three, belongs to the New Dawn Association of Villa Tejada. Her main occupation is the sale of automobile spare parts at the 16 de Julio street market in the city of El Alto. She started out selling a few hub caps here and there, on the streets and at bus stops. Four years later she owns her own market stall and stocks a great variety of spare parts.

Sofia needs this loan to increase her inventory and sales, as she alone is responsible for supporting her children and providing for their education. Her husband only helps with clothing and some school expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Rosario McFaull, Kiva Volunteer.

Sofía V. Guarachi, casada, y madre de tres hijos, pertenece a la asociación Nuevo Amanecer de Villa Tejada, su principal actividad es la venta de repuestos de automóviles en la Feria 16 de Julio de la ciudad de El Alto. Comenzó con muy poco, solo vendía un par de tapa aros, y deambulando por las calles y paradas de auto transporte. Ya pasaron 4 años de eso, y hoy en día es dueña de un puesto propio de venta, y además un gran surtido de repuestos para automóviles. Sofía precisa de capital para poder incrementar su mercadería, ya que debe generar recursos con el fin de asegurar los estudios de sus hijos, ya que ella trabaja sola, el esposo solamente colabora en la vestimenta y estudios de los hijos, el resto de la carga familiar recae en ella.

loans.use: To purchase additional merchandise

loans.name: Jimena

texts.en:
Jimena V. is a mother of three and is married to a dentist who specializes in dentures and crowns. Together they started a dental laboratory out of their own home, making dentures, crowns, etc., out of materials such as acrylic, gold and chrome. They have been in business for 14 years, starting out with a few consultations and working with low cost acrylic.

Jimena is requesting this loan to invest in her laboratory, to purchase higher quality materials for dentures and crowns, including porcelain and other flexible materials which are in more demand and will improve her husband's professional results.

Translated from Spanish by Rosario McFaull, Kiva Volunteer.

Jimena Carola V. Pardo, es madre de 3 hijos, y esta casada con un odontólogo protesista, con quien instalaron un laboratorio dental en su propio domicilio, trabajando con prótesis dentales en distintos materiales como ser acrílicos, oro, cromo y otros. Esta es una actividad que desarrollan hace 14 años, comenzando con algunas consultas simplemente y trabajando en acrílico, material que se considera de bajo costo. Jimena precisa de capital para poder invertir en su laboratorio, con el fin de mejorar los materiales con los que trabaja, incluir trabajos en porcelana y otros materiales flexibles, que son más comerciales y reditúan mejor el trabajo profesional de su esposo.

loans.use: to invest in her laboratory, to purchase higher quality materials for dentures and crowns

loans.name: Santa Martina

texts.es:
Santa Martina C. Z. is from the city of Bluefields. She is 45 years old and is married to Kuen Yan, who is from China and is 65 years old. They have 4 children who are all adults, married, and no longer live with them. Mrs. C. administers the business, which consists of making noodles and chop suey and selling them in bags. This business is familiar to both Mrs. C. and to Kuen Yan, but due to his age, he doesn’t work. Therefore, all the responsibility falls on Mrs. C., who has learned from her husband how to prepare the noodles and chop suey.

The advantage of this business is that they have more than 30 years of experience in it, and for more than 20 years Mr. Yan has been transmitting his knowledge to his wife, Martina C.. The quality of the product is well known in this city where people of Chinese origin enjoy prestige from making this food. Their clients are the many families that buy this product for their own consumption, and also restaurants that buy it for re-sale.

Each hundred pound sack of flour costs $27.00, each bucket of cooking oil costs $22.00, each box of eggs costs $3.00, and each sack of charcoal costs $4.00.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

Santa Martina C. Z. es originaria de la ciudad de Bluefields, tiene 45 años de edad, es casada con el señor Kuen Yan de origen chino y quien tiene 65 años de edad. Ambos tienen 4 hijos todos adultos y casados, los 4 hijos viven aparte de la pareja. La señora C. administra el negocio que consiste en preparar tallarines y chopsuei y venderlos en bolsas. Este negocio es familiar tanto de la señora C. Z. como de su marido Kuen Yan, pero por su edad este no trabaja por lo que toda la responsabilidad recae en ella quien a aprendido de su marido a preparar tallarines y chop suey. La ventaja del negocio es que cuentan con una experiencia de mas de 30 años y de estos por mas de 20 años le a estado transmitiendo el señor Yan a su esposa Martina C.. La calidad del producto es conocida en esta ciudad en donde las personas de origen chino gozan de prestigio en la elaboracion de este producto. Sus clientes son muchas familias que compran este producto para autoconsumo y tambien restaurantes que lo compran para su venta. Cada quintal de harina se compra en 27 dolares, cada balde de aceite se compra en 22 dolares, cada cajilla de huevo se compra en 3 dolares y cada saco de carbon cuesta 4 dolares.

loans.use: To buy 5 one hundred-pound sacks of flour, 5 buckets of cooking oil, 5 boxes of eggs, and 5 sacks of charcoal.

payments.comment: Le tocaba pagar el 12 de diciembre del 2007 pero pago el 10 de diciembre del 2007.

loans.name: Sandra

texts.en:
"The Untouchables" is the name of the entreneurial group that Sandra C. de Rojas, a married mother of a 12 year old girl, belongs to. Her main occupation is the sale of small electrical appliances on credit. She sells her products in the street fairs and markets of the city of El Alto. She got started 8 years ago, thanks to the help of a good friend who makes the necessary contacts that allow her to buy her products. Prior to this business, Sandra ran a small restaurant out of her own home, but due to a lack of time and assistance, she was forced to close it down.

Today, Sandra needs working capital to buy more merchandise for the upcoming holiday season, a time when her sales typically increase significantly. This will allow her to generate the income necessary to help support her family and ensure her daughter's well being.

Translated from Spanish by Rosario McFaull, Kiva Volunteer.

Las Intocables, es el nombre de la asociación a la que pertenece Sandra C. de Rojas, mujer casada y madre de una hija de 12 años, que se dedica a la compra y venta de electrodomésticos al crédito. Su principal mercado se encuentra en ferias y mercados de la ciudad de El Alto, lugares donde deambula ofreciendo su mercadería. Ya son 8 años que se dedica a esta actividad, iniciándose gracias a una amiga que le hace los contactos necesarios para ella poder adquirir esta mercadería. Antes de esto, Sandra se dedicaba a la atención de un restaurante en su propio domicilio, pero por falta de tiempo y ayuda, tuvo que cerrar. Hoy en día, Sandra precisa de más capital, tomando en cuenta la proximidad de las fiestas de fin de año, temporada muy alta en ventas principalmente de su mercadería. De esta manera asegurar los ingresos de su familia y principalmente el bienestar de su pequeña hija.

loans.use: To purchase additional merchandise to meet increased demand during the upcoming holiday season

loans.name: Lucía

texts.en:
Lucia Irene C. is a member of the Snow White association in Villa Adela, city of El Alto. Her main occupation is the sale of lingerie and baby clothes in the various street fairs and open air markets of El Alto. She has only been doing this for the past 2 years, as prior to that time she dedicated herself full time to taking care of her young son. When her son's needs grew and she didn't have enough money to cover expenses, Lucia went off to work.

Today, Lucia needs working capital to invest in more inventory for the upcoming holiday season. She would like to stock up before the prices she pays go up and cut into her profits.

Translated from Spanish by Rosario McFaull, Kiva Volunteer.

Lucia Irene C., pertenece a la asociación Blanca Nieves de Villa Adela en la ciudad de El Alto. Lucía se dedica a la venta de lencería, ropa interior y ropa de bebé, de forma ambulante en las ferias y mercados de las distintas zonas de la ciudad de El Alto. Son solamente dos años que se dedica a esta actividad, ya que antes de esto, Lucía solo se dedicaba al cuidado de su pequeño hijo, pero al ver que las necesidades del menor continuamente aumentaban, y el dinero no alcanzaba, tuvo que comenzar a trabajar. Hoy en día Lucia precisa de capital para poder incrementar la variedad de su mercadería, aprovechando de aprovisionarse para las fiestas de fin de año, ya que en esa temporada los precios suben y la ganancia se reduce.

loans.use: To invest in more inventory for the upcoming holiday season

loans.name: Juana

texts.en:
Juana is 33 years old and has two biological children, aged 16 and 17. She also has an adopted child as well as looking after two of her husband’s nieces. Juana's husband’s name is Radame de la Cruz.

Juana only has a middle school education, but all her children are going to school and she hopes they will continue to do so. She has been an Esperanza client for one year and has already successfully paid back two loans (one for 150 USD and one for 240 USD). Now she is applying for a third loan.

With each loan Juana started a new application of her business. She began by using her first loan to sell ice cream at the local school. With her second loan she began to include other products in her sales, such as corn, pork, and empanadas and started selling from her home. With this third loan, she wants to include natural medicinal products, which she can buy from the pharmacy in El Seybo and bring to her community. She plans on putting her profits back into her business in order to keep expanding. Right now Juana lives in a house owned by her mother, but eventually she wants to be able to buy her own house for her family.

loans.use: To add natural medicinal products to her inventory

loans.name: Fanny

texts.en:
Fanny, married and the mother of a one year old son, belongs to the Fortitude association in Villa Tejada. Her main occupation is the preparation and sale of desserts made of milk and gelatine (called harlequins in Bolivia), which she sells in street fairs and open air markets. Prior to this business, Fanny worked with her mother sewing and selling clothes. They owned a market stall in the 16 de Julio market. Unfortunately, Fanny's mother passed away recently and she was unable to keep the business going on her own.

She has been in business for 3 months now, in an effort to generate the income necessary to help support her young son. She is requesting this loan to buy raw materials and supplies necessary to continue her business and to establish herself and her products in a very competitive market.

Translated from Spanish by Rosario McFaull, Kiva Volunteer.

Fanny Ercilla A., casada y madre de un pequeño de apenas 1 añito de edad, pertenece a la asociación Fortaleza de Villa Tejada, Su actividad principal es la preparación y venta de postres hechos a base de leche y gelatina (arlequines), los cuales ella sola prepara y vende de forma ambulante en los mercados y ferias de la zona. Antes de dedicarse a esta actividad, Fanny colaboraba y trabajaba con su madre en la confección y venta de ropa. Eran dueñas de un puesto en la Feria 16 de Julio. Lastimosamente la mamá de Fanny falleció y a raíz de esto, no pudo proseguir con el negocio de confección. Son tres meses que ella viene realizando este trabajo con el fin de generar los recursos necesarios para la manutención de su pequeño hijo. Por tal motivo Fanny precisa de dinero para mejorar su producto y abastecerse de suministros que le permitan continuar y establecer su producto en un mercado muy competitivo.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials and supplies needed to make and sell her products in a very competitive market

loans.name: Sabina

texts.en:
Sabina is 54 years old and has nine children and eleven grandchildren. She is no longer married, but 9 of her children/grandchildren live with her in her house. -

Sabina is illiterate, however, she was able to send four of her nine children to school. She is pictured in front of her women’s association meeting center, where her group meets every two weeks to pay back their loan installments.

Sabina has been an Esperanza client for one year and has already successfully paid back two loans (one for 150 USD and one for 240 USD). Now she is applying for a third loan. She used to sell her small goods on the street: items such as shampoo and lotions, but with her first loan from Esperanza she was able to buy a small store where she is able to sell gasoline to vehicles passing by, particularly motorcycles (the main means of transportation in her area).

Sabina says her profits have increased greatly from having the loans. She still sells her small products, but she does it from her little gas station. This way she is able to attract more customers. She is going to use this next loan to buy more products to sell at her gas station and keep expanding her business.

loans.use: To buy additional merchandise for her business

loans.name: Alejandrina

texts.en:
President of the Ninawara Association of Villa Tejada in the city of El Alto, Alejandrina A. is a divorced mother of seven. Her main occupation is the sale of lamb and pork meat at the Plaza Garita de Lima market in La Paz. She has done this work since she was 18 years old and with time, has become one of the longest tenured vendors in the area. She owns her own market stall, but has given it to her sons to work while she tends someone else's stall.

Dona Alejandrina needs a loan to realize her long held dream of opening a small grocery store and butcher shop, with the purpose of generating enough income to cover her home expenses, where she still lives with some of her daughters and sons-in-law.

Translated from Spanish by Rosario McFaull, Kiva Volunteer.

Presidenta de la asociación Ninawara de Villa Tejada en la ciudad de El Alto, Alejandrina A., divorciada y madre de 7 hijos, se dedica a la venta de carne de cordero y carne de cerdo en el mercado de la Plaza Garita de Lima en la ciudad de La Paz. Esta actividad, Alejandrina la realiza desde sus 18 años de edad, y con el paso del tiempo logró establecerse como una de las vendedoras más antiguas de la zona, ella cuenta con un puesto propio, pero este puesto ha sido cedido a sus hijos, para que ellos lo trabajen, mientras tanto, ella atiende en un puesto prestado. La señora Alejandrina, precisa de dinero para poder realizar su sueño de instalar una tienda de venta de abarrotes y una carnicería, con el fin de poder generar recursos suficientes para correr con los gastos de su casa, donde aún vive con algunos de sus hijas, y con sus hiernos.

loans.use: To open a grocery store and butcher shop

loans.name: Gregoria

texts.es:
Gregoria C. Callisaya, works as a seamstress, creating blankets, duvets and other items as contracted or requested by her clients. Gregoria has been working as a seamstress for over 15 years, selling her wares at all the fairs in the city of El Alto, mainly for domestic use, as she is self-employed and doesn’t have the man-power to produce items in large amounts. Gregoria’s intention is to purchase a stall in the area of Villa Dolores, with the goal of establishing a place to sell all of her preparations, as well making an operational base for contacts and contracts. She already has the machinery necessary for the production of her goods, it is for this reason why she only requires money to purchase a stall as it will really fulfill her needs, in view of the fact that she has two children to maintain and a spouse who only works as a driver.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Pendleton, Kiva Volunteer.

Gregoria C. Callisaya, se dedica a la costura y confección de fundas, edredones, y otros que vende a pedido o contrato, según el requerimiento de sus clientes. Ya son más de 15 ños que Gregoria viene desarrollando este trabajo, vendiendo por todas las ferias de la ciudad de El Alto, principalmente para uso doméstico, ya que siendo una empresa unipersonal, no produce por mayor o en gran cantidad. La intención de Gregoria es la compra de un puesto de venta en la zona de Villa Dolores, con el fin de establecer un lugar de venta de todas sus confecciones, y hacer una base de operaciones para contactos y contratos. Posee la maquinaria necesaria para la producción de estas confecciones, por lo que solo precisa de capital para poder realizar la compra de este puesto que en definitiva colaborará mucho con sus intereses, en vista de que tiene dos hijos que mantener y un esposo que solo trabaja como transportista.

loans.use: Requires money to purchase a stall as it will really fulfill her needs, in view of the fact that she has two children to maintain and a spouse who only works as a driver.

loans.name: Valentina

texts.en:
Valentina is 49 years old and has six children and 14 grandchildren. She was able to send three of her children to school.She has been an Esperanza client for one year and has already successfully paid back two loans (one for 150 USD and one for 240 USD). Now she's applying for a third loan.

Valentina buys her clothes in the nearby city of La Romana and sells them out of her house. She says her business is better than the competition in the nearby cities, because the people in her community don´t have to pay money to travel in order to go shopping.

Valentina is going to use her next loan to start construction on a little store abutting her house, so she doesn´t have to keep selling her clothes from her porch.

loans.use: To build a small space next to her house where she can sell clothes

loans.name: Elisa

texts.es:
Pajchani, when translated in Spanish, means “claridad” or clarity and transparency when translated into English. Pajchani is the name of the association to which Elisa Y., mother of 4 school children, belongs. Elisa works in the sale of office and school supplies made from plastic materials such as book covers, folders, laminates, and others products. This is how she makes a living and has been doing so for 12 years. In the beginning, she bought these products and resold them at the door of the Internal Revenue Office. Over time and with a lot of hard work, Elisa was able to purchase the necessary machinery in order to manufacture these products and transfer her place of work to the offices of Identifications of the National Police. Elisa requires this money in order to purchase raw materials and get her business ready in time for the school season in January of next year when she makes her biggest sales.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Pendleton, Kiva Volunteer.

Pajchani, traducido al castellano quiere decir claridad, transparencia, es el nombre de la asociación a la que pertenece Elisa Y., madre de 4 niños, todos aún en edad escolar. Elisa se dedica a trabajar con plásticos, forros, folders, carpetas, plastificaciones y otros, son los trabajos que realiza y con el cual subsiste, generando sus propios recursos. Ya son 12 años que se dedica a este oficio, en un inicio, ella compraba estos productos y revendía en la puerta de las oficinas de Impuestos Internos. Con el tiempo y con mucho trabajo, Elisa logra la compra de la maquinaria necesaria para la fabricación de este producto y traslada su lugar de trabajo a las oficinas de Identificaciones de la Policía Nacional. Elisa precisa de capital con el fin de abastecerse de materia prima y preparar su negocio para el mes de enero del próximo año, mes en el que se inicia la temporada escolar y representa alta venta.

loans.use: Elisa requires this money in order to purchase raw materials and get her business ready in time for the school season in January of next year, when she makes her biggest sales.

loans.name: Betty

texts.es:
Betty C. Mamani is the mother of three children, the youngest of which is only 2 months old. She works in the sale of electronic domestic products in the Eloy Salmón area of the city of La Paz. She has been doing this job for 14 years, starting with just a few products such transistor radios, batteries and small products like that. She buys her products from vendors at the Uyustus fair in order to resell them and make money for herself. Saturation of the market in her area of these products does not allow her to make the kind of sales she desires, so she also works as a wash woman on days when sales are low. For this reason, she is asking for money in order to supply her stall with greater quality and a better variety of products to offer to all of the numerous consumers.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Pendleton, Kiva Volunteer.

Betty C. Mamani, es madre de tres hijos, el menor apenas tiene 2 meses de nacido, se dedica a la venta de electrodomésticos en la zona Eloy Salmón de la ciudad de La Paz. Ya lleva 14 años en esta actividad, comenzando con muy poco, apenas unas pequeñas radios de transistores, baterías y algunos productos pequeños. Ella compra sus productos de mayoristas ubicados en la feria Uyustus, para luego revenderlos y generar sus propios recursos. La saturación en la oferta de estos productos en esa zona, no permite que Betty logre la venta deseada, por lo que se ve obligada a trabajar de lavandera, aquellos días de venta baja. Por tal motivo, precisa de capital para poder surtir más su puesto y tener mayor cantidad y variedad de productos que ofrecer al numeroso público que se da cita a comprar en esa zona.

loans.use: To supply her stall with greater quality and a better variety of products

loans.name: Blacina

texts.en:
Blacina is 48 years old and has three children (ages 16, 19, 21). She has a grandson who is 9 months old. She has been an Esperanza client for one year and has already successfully paid back two loans (one for 150 USD and one for 240 USD). Now she's applying for a third loan.

Blacina sells rice, chicken, and other typical Dominican food like ¨moro¨ at her little store, Colmado Blasina. She is pictured in front of her women’s association meeting center, where her group meets every two weeks to pay back the loan installments. She is going to use her third loan to include more merchandise in her Colmado (convenience store), such as more soft drinks and juices.

loans.use: To buy additional merchandise for her small food store

loans.name: Eduarda

texts.es:
Eduarda U. is a part of the group pertaining to Pajchani de Villa Tejada. She has a 13 year old son who is studying in highschool. Eduarda has two businesses which generate income. First, is the sale of footware which she buys buy the dozen and then sells individually in the Tumusla Street Fair in the city of La Paz. The second business, and the one which generates more income, is the sale of beer. For this, she travels to other locations, mainly those that celebrate folkloric holidays, anniversaries and other events, where there is a lot of beer consumption. If things are good, this generates more income, but it's not a regular activity.

Eduarda will use the loan to continue with her businesses, mainly the sale of beer. Without the loan, she will not be able to purchase the beer to sell, and will not be able to generate the income she needs to take care of her son.

Eduarda U., pertenece a la asociación Pajchani de Villa Tejada, es madre de un niño de 13 años, el cual se encuentra estudiando en colegio. Eduarda tiene dos actividades que le generan ingresos, la primera, es la venta de calzados, los que ella compra por docena y vende por unidad en la Feria de la calle Tumusla en la ciudad de La Paz. La segunda actividad y la que le genera mejores ingresos, es la venta de cerveza, para esto ella viaja a otras localidades, principalmente aquellas que celebran fiestas folclóricas, entradas folclóricas, aniversarios y otros, donde el consumo de cerveza es por mayor. Si bien esta actividad le genera mejores ingresos, es una actividad ocasional. A tal efecto, Eduarda precisa de capital para poder continuar con sus negocios, principalmente el de la cerveza, ya que sin capital, no puede adquirir la cerveza por tanto no puede vender y generar recursos para la manutención de su hijo.

Translated by Kiva volunteer, Emily Charnes

loans.use: This loan is to invest in her business selling beer. Without the loan, she will not be able to purchase the beer to sell, and will not be able to generate the income she needs to take care of her son.

loans.name: Felisia

texts.en:
Felisia is 26 years old and has a three-year-old daughter who is just starting preschool. She lives with her husband and her baby in her husband´s mother´s house. -The name of her Colmado (convenience store) is ¨La Flor de Montecristi¨. At her store she sells products such as rice, cooking oil, salsa, soap, and detergent.

This is the second loan Felisia has requested from Esperanza. She successfully paid back the first loan of 5000 pesos (150 USD), using her profits to further invest in her business.

Felicia buys her items from the neighboring town of El Seybo and sells them to people in her community . With her small business earnings, she wants to continue to put her child through school and eventually have her own house with her family. She wants to be able to live comfortably.

loans.use: To purchase additional merchandise for her small convenience store

loans.name: Concepción

texts.es:
Concepción C., mother of six and wife of a driver, belongs to an association called "Pajchani de Villa Tejada". She sells vegetables from a stall in the Rodríguez Market in the city of La Paz, Bolivia. She has done this for more than 18 years. She started to work with her in-laws, who in fact, started selling vegetables. Concepción works alone from seven days a week. Fortunately, she lives close to the market, which saves her on transportation expenses and product shipping costs. She needs the loan to continue her business in the market, for this is the only way to face the challenge of supporting her six children.

Translated from Spanish by Geraldine Kim, Kiva Volunteer. Concepción C., madre de 6 hijos y casada con un chofer, pertenece a la asociación Pajchani de Villa Tejada. Su principal actividad es la venta de verduras en un puesto instalado en el mercado Rodríguez de la ciudad de La Paz, Son más de 18 años en esta actividad, que comenzó con su suegra, fue ella precisamente quien la inició y le enseñó la venta de verduras y hortalizas. Concepción trabaja de lunes a domingo, vende sola, esto gracias a la cercanía de su casa con el mercado, esto ayuda principalmente en el ahorro del gasto en transporte y traslado de sus productos. Ella precisa de capital para poder continuar con el negocio y el puesto de venta en el mercado, solo de esta manera podrá hacer frente a la manutención de sus 6 hijos.

loans.use: She needs the capital to continue her business, which is the only way to face the challenge of supporting her six children.

loans.name: Marcela

texts.es:
Marcela is married to a tailor and has four children. She is a member of the Pajchani de Villa Tejada in the city of El Alto. She is dedicated to making and selling skirts and tablecloths, which she has been doing for 17 years. The tradition started with her oldest sister, who worked at a dressmaking factory and learned the craft and later passed it on to her siblings. Her main market is in the Villa Dolores zone of El Alto, and she also sells her goods at festivals and other markets. Currently she works with her eldest daughter, who has already learned the trade and makes high-quality goods. Marcela needs capital to be able to purchase more materials and fabrics, with the goal of producing a larger quantity of merchandise to prepare her business for the increased demand at the end of the year.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

Marcela N., esta casada con un sastre, y es madre de 4 hijos, pertenece a la asociación Pajchani de Villa Tejada en la ciudad de El Alto. Ella se dedica a la confección y venta de polleras y mantas, actividad que realiza desde sus 17 años, es una tradición que ha comenzado con su hermana mayor, quien trabajaba en una fábrica de confección, donde aprendió este arte y luego lo transmitió a sus hermanos. Su principal mercado se encuentra en la zona de Villa Dolores y también en las principales ferias y mercados de la zona. Actualmente trabaja colaborada por su hija mayor, quien ya aprendió el oficio y genera trabajos de gran calidad en el acabado. Marcela precisa de capital para poder comprar más material y telas, con el fin de producir mayor cantidad de mercadería con el fin de preparar su taller para la demanda de fin de año.

loans.use: Marcela wants to be able to purchase more fabrics and materials in order to increase production to be prepared for the high demand at the end of the year.

loans.name: Gaby

texts.es:
Gaby is dedicated to making women's pants. She started this activity two ago after her previous job as a cell phone operator ended when new laws and rates set in. So she entered the dressmaking business and thanks to her sister-in-law, who taught her the craft. Currently she has a post at the fairgrounds in El Alto, which was given to her by her sister-in-law as well, and she uses that as her operational base to get contracts and orders. Gaby needs capital to be able to purchase more materials, namely fabrics, which will allow her to produce a larger quantity of merchandise so she'll be ready for the Christmas season. Only then will she be able to earn the necessary resources to move her family (husband and three children) ahead, keeping in mind her eldest daughter will soon give birth.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

Gaby P., se dedica a la confección de pantalones de tela para damas. Hace dos años que se dedica a esta actividad, ya que antes se dedicaba a ser punto de llamadas de celular (chalequero), pero a raíz de las nuevas leyes y disposiciones del gobierno respecto a la tarifación de las llamadas de telefonía movil, tuvo que cambiar de rubro. Es así que Gabi ingresa al mundo de la confección y gracias a la ayuda de su cuñada, quien le enseñó el oficio. Actualmente ella posee un puesto de venta en la Feria 16 de Julio de la ciudad de El Alto, puesto que también fue cedido por su cuñada, y donde ha instalado su base de operaciones para contactar contratos y pedidos. Gaby precisa de capital para poder comprar mayor cantidad de materiales, principalmente telas que le permitirán producir mayor cantidad de mercadería que será puesta a la venta para la temporada navideña. Solo así podrá generar los recursos necesarios para salir adelante con su esposo y sus tres hijos, tomando en cuenta que su hija menor apenas cuenta con días de recién nacida.

loans.use: Gaby needs capital to be able to purchase more materials, namely fabrics, which will allow her to produce a larger quantity of merchandise so she'll be ready for the Christmas season.

loans.name: Angelica Ricardina

texts.es:
Angélica is a very happy and optimistic 37-year-old. She dedicates herself daily to agriculture, thanks to lessons from her family when she was very young when she would follow them out into the fields. Her perseverance and dilligence has allowed her to begin a new task of selling her goods and other items. Things started well and after the small store had been established she decided to spend more time with the crops since inclement weather had endangered a large portion of the planting. She decided to work at night and little by little recovered most of the affected area. But one night while she was out in the fields some thieves took advantage of her absence and made off with everything they could find. This act set her back a lot since the harvest wasn't coming for months and the small store couldn't help her family enough to cover their most urgent needs. For this reason, Angélica is requesting a loan of $325 with the goal of setting up the store quickly to secure the well-being and peace of mind for her family.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

Angélica tiene 37 años es una mujer optimista y muy alegre; a diario se dedica a realizar labores agrícolas; gracias a las enseñanzas de su familia cuando aún era muy pequeña y los acompañaba al campo; su perseverancia y diligencia le han permitido incursionar en un nuevo rubro; la venta de artículos de primera necesidad. Cuando las cosas marchaban bien y el pequeño negocio de ventas se había establecido decidió otorgarle mayor tiempo a su labor agrícola debido a que el inclemente clima estaba dañando gran parte de la siembra. Para evitar que este daño se incremente decidió realizar jornadas nocturnas, poco a poco y luego de interminables noches de trabajo las cosas estaban funcionando y ya había recuperado parte de la zona afectada. Sin embargo una noche mientras dedicaba el mayor de sus esfuerzos para culminar su labor unos ladrones aprovecharon la ausencia de la familia completa para llevarse todo lo que encontraban a su paso. Este hecho los ha perjudicado mucho debido a que para el tiempo de cosecha aún faltan meses y la pequeña bodega no los podrá ayudar por más tiempo a cubrir sus necesidades más urgentes. Por esta razón solicitan el préstamo de 325 dólares con el propósito de implementar en menor tiempo la bodega a fin de procurarle bienestar y tranquilidad a su familia. Ayudemos a esta humilde familia trabajadora a forjarse un futuro mejor.

loans.use: Setting up food store

loans.name: Elvira

texts.es:
Elvira C., mother of six, is married to a public servant. She is a member of an association called "Pajchani de Villa Tejada". She dedicates herself to the making and selling of tailored garments like blankets, sweaters, scarves, and others, which she sells at El Alto's fair in the summer. She does not own her own store; she wanders around to sell her items only two days of the week. The other days, she is occupied in making and sewing the articles. Currently, she works with her daughters. They've learned the trade well - they produce about 20 blankets per week and are able to sell everything they make.
