They have three machines that allow them to complete their projects on time to meet customers' demands.

Elvira needs the loan to be able to increase her inventory, so she will be prepared for year-end festivities, where she has considerable source of income. This is the only way she will be able to face the challenge of providing for her children's education.

Translated from Spanish by Geraldine Kim, Kiva Volunteer.

Elvira C., esta casada con un servidor público, y madre de 6 hijos, es miembro de la asociación Pajchani de Villa Tejada, se dedica a la confección y venta de prendas de vestir tejidas a máquina, como ser mantas, chompas, chalinas, y otros, que vende en la feria 16 de Julio de El Alto. No posee un puesto propio, por lo que tiene que deambular para poder vender, sólo sale a vender dos días a la semana, los demás días los ocupa en la confección. Actualmente trabaja con sus hijas, ellas han aprendido bien el oficio, produciendo aproximadamente 20 mantas a la semana, y vendiendo todo lo producido. Posee tres máquinas que le permiten trabajar a tiempo completo para satisfacer la demanda existente.

Elvira precisa de capital para poder incrementar su mercadería, de esta forma preparar su negocio para las fiestas de fin de año, temporada que se considera de alta venta. Solo así podrá hacer frente a los gastos de estudio de sus 6 hijos.

loans.use: Elvira needs the capital to be able to increase her inventory, so she will be prepared for year-end festivities, where she gets a considerable source of income.  This is the only way she will be able to face the challenge of providing for her six children's education.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.es:
Victoria Cortéz Arias is single. She is a member of the Korikantutitas Association in Villa Tejada, in the city of El Alto. Her business is making doll clothes, miniature clothing, and other artesanal products which she sells at national markets for miniatures. She worked in this field for over 15 years. She strives to support herself with this business, selling to small merchants by the dozen. She has a kiosk on Graneros Street in La Paz where she also sells her products in bulk. At present, she works with a partner who helps make the necessary trips to miniature fairs throughout the country. She needs capital to increase her merchandise. In this way, she can improve her sales and thereby her income.

Translated by Bianca Vargas, Kiva Volunteer.

Victoria Cortéz Arias, soltera , es miembro de la asociación Korikantutitas de Villa Tejada en la ciudad de El Alto, su principal actividad es la confección de prendas de vestir en miniatura, ropa de muñeca y otras artesanías, que vende en todas las ferias de miniatura a nivel nacional. Son más de 15 años dedicada a esta actividad, Victoria intenta sobrevivir con este negocio, vendiendo siempre por docena a aquellos comerciantes minoristas. Ella posee un puesto de venta en la calle Graneros de la ciudad de La Paz, donde de igual manera vende sus trabajos al por mayor. En la actualidad, Victoria trabaja con una socia, la que le colabora principalmente a realizar los viajes necesarios a las ferias de miniatura en todo el interior del país. Ella precisa de capital para poder incrementar su mercadería, de esta manera mejorar su venta y principalmente sus ingresos.

loans.use: To buy merchandise.

texts.id:
M. (23) is married. she was active member of yamida for 1 years ago. To help support her family, M. sells snacks and household goods in a kiosk in front of her house. From the kiosk, she earns about $10 per day. M. needs $100 loan to expand her kiosk's offering and fix her kiosk. Hopefully with the renovation and expansion, she can better help her husband and increase her family income.

Translated from Indonesian by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use:
$ 50 to expand product offering
$ 50 for kiosk renovation

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.en:
Mercedes sells about 4 chickens a day, and a 4 lb. chicken usually sells for 100 pesos (about US$ 3). She has three children, but only supports two as one has already married and left the house. She lives with her husband, two children, and her husband's mother. Her mother-in-law is blind, and that has made things difficult because she is unable to help out with much around the house.

Mercedes is also the group coordinator; she works hard to make sure that her partners are doing okay with their businesses, and that everyone repays on time. She is a warm, friendly, and hard-working woman who tries each day to sell a little more, and do a little better.

NOTE: This $750 loan will fund Mercedes' business as well as four other businesses in her solidarity group. She and four other women micro-entrepreneurs came to Esperanza and formed their group, Paz de Esperanza (Peace of Hope). They have all gone through Esperanza's business training program and will receive equal shares of the loan to invest in their respective businesses and will pay back the loan together. The entire group must pay in full and on time, otherwise group members must make up the deficit before any payment can be made. This creates accountability among the group members because each one shares in the struggles and successes of the other members in their group.

loans.use: To invest in her business, which consists of selling poultry and cooked beans

loans.name: Dewi Komala

texts.id:
Dewi Komala rents the house she and her husband lives in with their 2 kids, Sifa (4.5 yrs) and Agil (9.5 months). As a housewife, Dewi needs to take care of her children while running her fried rice business. Her husband works as a seasonal construction worker who earns about $45 per month. However her husband's income is not enough to support their family as they need to spend $45 for living expenses and $25 for children tuition (their other kids in Java). Dewi sells her kiosk from a makeshift kiosk and tent. She sells fried rice in front of her rented home. She earns about $5 per day. She plans to use the loan to increase capital. Hopefully she can expand her business so she can better fulfill her family's need and tuition for her 4 children.

Translated from Indonesian by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva Volunteer

Dewi Komala tinggal di rumah kontrakan bersama suami dan 2 orang anaknya. Sifa – 4,5 tahun dan Agil – 9,5 bulan. Sebagai ibu rumah tangga – sembari menjalankan usaha nasi gorengnya - Dewi mengurus kedua anaknya yang masih kecil. Suaminya bekerja sebagai kuli bangunan – yang baru bekerja apabila ada proyek. Pendapatan per bulannya mencapai Rp 450.000,00. Penghasilannya saja tidak mencukupi untuk kebutuhan mereka. Per bulannya, mereka harus mengeluarkan Rp 450.000,00 untuk biaya hidup dan Rp 250.000,00 untuk biaya pendidikan anak (2 anak mereka yang di Jawa). Sarana yang digunakan Dewi untuk berjualan adalah rombong. Dia berjualan di depan rumah kontrakkannya. Keuntungan yang diperoleh perharinya mencapai Rp 50.000,00. Pinjaman yang diperoleh dia gunakan untuk tambahan modal. Harapannya supaya usahanya ini berkembang. Sehingga akan mampu memenuhi kebutuhan hidup keluarga, maupun biaya pendidikan keempat anaknya.

loans.use: Increase capital

loans.name: Ni Nengah Wedi

texts.id:
53 year old Ni Nengah Wedi is wife of Nengah Budiarta. She is still motivated to expand the pig farm that she started 6 months ago. Starting with a simple pen and 2 pigs, Ni Nengah Wedi had gone through 2 slaughter cycles. She farms local pig with "Babi Guling System" (slaughter in 3 months cycle). She earns about $15 per month in profit. With Dinari Loan of $150, Ni Nengah Wedi wants to buy 1 more piglets and 1 more breeding pig so she will have 4 pigs. Rest of the money will be used to buy feed concentrate, rice seeds, and wheat seeds for feeds. In her daily lifeNi Nengah Wedi only lives with her husband as her children are married already. Ni Nengah Wedi is grateful that by farming pigs, she can increase her family income by $2 per day. She expects to increase her retirement savings using the extra profit.

Translated from Indonesian by Kresna Hartandi

Dalam Usia 53 tahun Ni Nengah Wedi istri dari Nengah Budiarta masih semangat dalam mengembangkan usaha ternak babi yang mulai dirintisnya sejak 6 bulan yang lalu. Dengan bermodalkan sebuah kandang sederhana dan dengan 2 ekor ternak peliharaan, Ni Nengah Wedi telah dapat melakukan panen 2 kali, karena ternak yang di pelihara jenis lokal ( Babi Bali ) dan Sistem Babi Guling ( panen tiap 3 bulan ). Keuntungan yang di dapat pun cukup lumayan yaitu Rp. 150.000 / bulan . Dengan pinjaman dari Dinari sebesar Rp. 1.500.000.-, kini Ni Nengah Wedi telah menambah 1 ekor bibit penggemukan dan 1 ekor induk sehinga peliharaanya sekarang menjadi 4 ekor. Sedangkan sisa uangnya di pergunakan untuk membeli pakan berupa Kosentrat , Dedak Padi dan Dedak Gandum. Dalam Keseharianya Ni Nengah Wedi, hanya tinggal berdua saja dengan suaminya karena anak –anaknya telah menikah dan tinggal dengan keluarganya masing – masing. Ni Nengah Wedi merasa bersyukur karena dengan beternak babi ia dapat menambah pendapatan keluarganya. Selain untuk biaya hidup sehari - hari yang mencapai Rp 20.000.- , Ni Nengah Wedi sudah bisa menyisihkan sedikit demi sedikit keuntungan yang di dapat untuk jaminan hari tuanya nanti.

loans.use: Purchase piglets and feeds

loans.name: Antonia

texts.en:
This is Antonia's first group loan from Esperanza; her group consists of herself and four other women. She is 18 years old and has one son, Anthony, who is two years old and is also in the picture.

Antonia lives with her husband and son in Batey, the migrant camps which house immigrant Haitian sugar-cane workers and their families. They live with five other people in one of the Batey company houses, barracks owned by the nationalized sugar-cane industry. Antonia and her husband are married, but not through the church.

Antonia hopes to use her portion of her group's loan to sell small convenience items to her community – wares like shampoo, soap, and little candies. She also dreams of moving out of the Batey camp and buying her own house. She stated that she wants to be able to have a small garden around her house.

NOTE: This $600 loan will fund Antonia's business as well as four other businesses in her solidarity group. She and four other women micro-entrepreneurs came to Esperanza and formed their group. They have all gone through Esperanza's business training program and will receive equal shares of the loan to invest in their respective businesses and pay back the loan together. The entire group must pay in full and on time, otherwise group members must make up the deficit before any payment can be made. This creates accountability among the group members because each one shares in the struggles and successes of the other members in their group.

loans.use: To buy personal care products and candies for resale

loans.name: I Gusti Ketut Sumant

texts.id:
Raising pigs are not only women's business. Many men are also in this occupation. Like is done by Gusti Ketut Sumantri, who since married to Ni Komang Sunistri has been in the pig farming business. Difficulties in finding work forced Sumantri who only finished 9th grade to create his own field of employment. His choice to be pig farmer came from his minimum capital of only Rp500,000 (about US$55). Initially his profit was minimal, only Rp75,000 (about $8)/month from his 2 piogs. This does not stop his hope to expand the business. From his wife support and requirements as head of household who has to raise 2 children, who now go to Grade school, Sumantri is encouranged to add his raised animals. With a loan of Rp 1,500,000 (about $165) from Dinari Sumantri now raise 4 piglets, and 1 mother pig. His profit increased. Because besides raising piglets, Sumantri could sell feedstock to people nearby. In 6 months Sumantri could sell Rp5,000,000 (about $550), with a profit of Rp3,500,000 (about $385)/6 months or Rp550,000 (about $60)/month. From this he supports his daily family needs.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Memelihara babi bukan saja dilakukan oleh para wanita saja . Tidak sedikit kaum laki-laki juga menekuni usaha ini. Seperti apa yang dilakukan oleh I Gusti Ketut Sumantri yang sejak menikahi Ni Komang Sunistri telah menekuni beternak babi . Sulitnya mencari pekerjaan membuat Sumantri yang hanya lulusan SMP ini , bertekad untuk menciptakan lapangan kerja sendiri. Beternak babi menjadi pilihannya karena dengan pertimbangan biaya yang di miliki sangat minim yaitu Rp 500.000.- Awalnya keuntungan yang di dapat oleh Sumantri sangatlah tipis hanya Rp. 75.000 .- / bulan dari 2 ekor ternak peliharaanya. Tapi hal itu tak memupus harapannya untuk mengembangkan usahanya itu. Dengan dorongan dari istri dan juga tuntutan sebagai kepala keluarga yang harus menanggung 2 orang anaknya yang sekarang sudah duduk di bangku sekolah dasar, Sumantri bertambah semangat untuk menambah ternak peliharaanya . Dengan pinjaman modal dari Dinari Rp 1.500.000.- Sumantri kini memelihara 4 ekor ternak babi penggemukan dan telah mempunyai 1 ekor induk babi. Keuntungan yang di peroleh Sumantri pun kini berlipat ganda . Karena disamping memelihara penggemukan, Sumantri juga telah bisa menyediakan bibit untuk warga disekitarnya. Dalam enam bulan hasil produksi Sumantri sekarang mencapai Rp 5 .000.000.- dengan ke untungan bersih Rp. 3.500.000.- 6 bln atau Rp. 550.000.- / bulan . Dari hasil itulah Sumantri memenuhi semua kebutuhan sehari- hari keluarganya .

loans.use:
To buy feedstock and mother pig

Membeli bibit babi dan induk

loans.name: Ni Ketut Desih

texts.id:
Food stall business has been Ni Ketut Desih preoccupation since one year. At 60, she is still productive. So is her husband, who works as a tenant farmer. From her 8 children, only one is still under their resposibility, finishing highschool. The other seven already have their own family. The food stall she rents for Rp5000.00/day. She starts to sell from 1:00 PM to 7:00PM. Distance between her home to the foodstall is about 50 meters. Sales per day is about Rp200,000.00 (about US$22). After expenses her net profit are about Rp50,000.00 ($5.50)/day. Although they are growing old, they do not want to be a burden to their children. This business besides tenant farming are their hope.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Usaha warung makan ini baru ditekuni Ni Ketut Desih setahun yang lalu. Di usianya yang 60 tahun dia masih produktif. Demikian pula suaminya. Suaminya bekerja sebagai petani. Dari 8 anak yang dimilikinya, hanya satu yang masih menjadi tanggungannya – tamat SMA. Ketujuh anak lainnya sudah berkeluarga. Warung makan yang dipakai dia kontrak dengan Rp 5.000,00 per harinya. Dia mulai berjualan pukul 13.00 Wita – 19.00 Wita. Jarak rumah dengan warung makannya kurang lebih 50 m. Dalam sehari dia dapat memperoleh Rp 200.000,00. Setelah dipotong modal, keuntungan bersihnya sekitar Rp 50.000,00. Memang dia dan suaminya sudah menjadi tua, akan tetapi mereka tidak mau menjadi tanggungan bagi anak – anak mereka. Usaha ini harapan mereka, selain menjadi petani.

loans.use:
To buy rice, vegetables, fish and meat

Membeli beras, sayuran, ikan, dan daging.

loans.name: Ni Luh Putu Yasini A

texts.id:
Luh Putu Yasini Arthi, born 1971 is a tough woman in her work as housewife as well helping her husband who is a meatball seller. All her work she does between 5:00AM -12:00PM. Still besides those busy times, this mother of Putu Reditiani and Made Reditiana still has time to run her own pig farming business. She does this to add income to supplement her daily living needs. Started with 1 mother pig, Luh Putu Yasini could produce 10 piglets within 6 months. After raising them another 3 months, she could sell those piglets for Rp150,000 (about US$16.50)/piece. In one year Luh Putu Yasini could farm 2X, and sales could reach up to Rp3,000,000 (US$330), depending on number of piglets born. With additional capital of Rp1,500,00 (about $165) Luh Putu plans to add another mother pig, and the rest being used to build a simple stall, so that her pigs could be shielded from heat and rain, so that their could grow better. So that sales price could be higher too.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Luh Putu Yasini Arthi wanita kelahiran tahun 1971 ini begitu ulet dalam melakukan pekerjaanya, baik selaku ibu rumah tangga maupun membantu pekerjaan suaminya yang berprofesi sebagai penjual bakso keliling . Semua pekerjaan itu dikerjakannya dengan cekatan setiap hari mulai jam 5 pagi sampai jam 12 siang Namun begitu, disela - sela kesibukan itu, ibu dari Putu Reditiani dan Made Reditiana ini juga masih sempat mengurus usahanya yakni beternak babi. Usaha ini dilakukannya karena dapat menghasilkan pendapatan yang cukup untuk menambah biaya kebutuhan hidup sehari-hari. Dengan berawal dari 1 induk, usaha ternak Luh Putu Yasini bisa menghasilkan 10 ekor anak dalam 6 bln. Setelah dipelihara kurang lebih 3 bulan, anak babi itu bisa dijual dengan harga Rp.150.000,- per ekor. Dalam setahun Luh Putu Yasini bisa panen 2 kali sehingga hasil yang di peroleh bisa mencapai Rp 3.000.000,- bahkan lebih tergantung pada banyaknya anak babi yang dilahirkan. Dengan mendapat tambahan modal dari Dinari Rp 1.500.000.- Luh Putu berencana menambah satu ekor induk lagi,dan sisanya akan di pergunakan untuk membuat kandang sederhana sehingga babinya bisa lebih aman terlindung dari panas dan hujan , sehingga pertumbuhannya pun lebih baik. Dengan demikian harga jualnya akan lebih tinggi.

loans.use:
To buy mother pig and build a better pig stall

Membeli induk babi dan membuat kandang yang lebih baik

loans.name: Ni Nengah Sumariani

texts.id:
Ni Nengah Sumariani lives in Warnasari, a village in Western Bali. Her hut is very simple, walls from woven bamboo, and floor of raw sand. Ni Nengah Sumariani lives with her husband and 3 children. Her husband is a tenant farmer. Economic condition in her area is quite harsh. For basic needs each day Rp25,000 (about US$3) is needed. Ni Nengah Sumariani works on 2 jobs to help her husband to fulfill family needs. From 6:00AM-12:00PM Ni Nengah Sumariani sells vegetables house to house around her neighborhood. However the profit is not sufficient to support her living expenses, since each day she only profit Rp15,000 (about US$1.80). So she added her pig farming business. Today Ni Nengah Sumariani raise 1 mother pig. 1 Mother pig could bore 6-12 piglets. After 4 months each could be sold for Rp900,000 (about $99). So maximium income for 4 months are Rp10,800,000 (about $120) minus feed cost of Rp 7,200,000 (about $80) from 12 piglets at Rp600,000 ($6.60) makes Rp3,600,000 (about ($40). So per month is about Rp 900,000 (about $100) or Rp30,000 ($3.30)/day.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Ni Nengah Sumariani tinggal di desa Warnasari, sebuah desa yang ada di Bali barat. Dengan kondisi rumah yang sangat sederhana, dinding terbuat dari gedek dan lantai tanah, Ni Nengah Sumariani tinggal bersama suami dan 3 orang anaknya. Suaminya berprofesi sebagai seorang Petani. Kondisi perekonomian dilingkungannya cukup sulit, karena untuk kebutuhan pokok sehari – hari diperlukan biaya sebesar Rp. 25.000.- Ni Nengah Sumariani menjalani dua profesi untuk membantu suaminya untuk memenuhi kebutuhan keluarganya. Pagi hari mulai pukul 06.00 sampai pukul 12.00 siang, Ni Nengah Sumariani berprofesi sebagi dagang Sayuran Keliling. Ni Nengah Sumariani menjajakan dagangannya disekitar lingkungannya. Namun, keuntungan yang didapatnya tidak mencukupi kebutuhan hidupnya, karena per hari hanya mendapat keuntungan Rp. 15.000.-. Hal itu ditutupinya dengan membuka usaha tambahan, yakni usaha ternak babi. Saat ini Ni Nengah Sumariani memelihara 1 ekor induk. Satu ekor induk bisa mempunyai anak 6 – 12 ekor. Setelah di pelihara selama 4 bulan, per ekor bisa dijual dengan harga Rp. 900.000. Jadi total pendapatan selama 4 bulan pemeliharaan adalah Rp. 10.800.000.- dikurangi biaya pakan Rp. 7.200.000.- ( 12 ekor @ Rp. 600.000.- ) adalah Rp. 3.600.000.-. Jadi keuntungan per bulan adalah Rp. 900.000.- atau Rp. 30.000.- per hari

loans.use:
To buy mother pig & animal feed to increase pig population

Membeli induk babi dan pakan untuk menambah populasi peliharaannya

loans.name: Ni Wayan Kolih

texts.id:
Ms. Wayan Kolih has been doing pig farming for a while, but always in simple and traditional way from pig feed as well as stall. With an initial capital of Rp1,600,000 (about US$176) Wayan Kolih bought 2 mother pigs. Every day Wayan Kolih has to spend Rp20,000 (about $2.20) for pig feed, since she fed them twice a day. Every 4 months her 2 mother pigs would bore piglets, that were ready to be sold 1.5 to 2 months after birth. Each pig could bore 6-10 piglets. From piglets sales Wayan Kolih could profit Rp1,500,000 (about $165)/6-months. This profit is used for school expenses of her 2 children who still sit in Middle school, since her husband's income aa a tenant farmer is not sure, and not enough to support a family. This profit is also used to repair her semi permanent home. Loan from Dinari will be used to buy better & quality piglets to be fattened, so that she could produce better pigs.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Ibu Wayan Kolih menekuni usaha beternak babi sudah sejak lama ,namun semuanya dilakukan secara sederhana dan tradisional ,Baik dari segi makanan maupun kandang babinya.Dengan modal awal sebesar Rp.1.600.000 Wayan Kolih bisa membeli 2 ekor induk babi.Setiap hari Wayan Kolih harus mengeluarkan biaya sebesar Rp.20.000 untuk makanan babinya,karena diberi makan dua kali dalam sehari. Setiap 4bulan sekali kedua induk babi ini akan melahirkan anaknya dan akan siap dijual setelah berumur 1,5 sampai 2 bulan sejak lahir.Satu ekor babi biasanya mempunyai anak 6 sampai 10 ekor.Dari penjualan anak-anak babi ini biasanya Wayan Kolih mendapat keuntungan Rp.1.500.000 setiap 6 bulan sekali.Keuntungan ini dipergunakan untuk biaya sekolah kedua anaknya yang kini duduk dibangku SMU, karena penghasilan suaminya sebagai seorang petani tidak tentu sehingga tidak bisa mencukupi kebutuhan keluarga,keuntungan ini juga sedikit demi sedikit dipergunakan untuk memperbaiki rumahnya yang kini masih semi permanen.Sedangkan pinjaman yang diperoleh dari DINARI dipergunakan untuk membeli bibit babi yang lebih bagus dan berkwalitas karena akan dipelihara sebagai penggemukan ,agar hasil yang didapat lebih baik.

loans.use:
To buy pig feedstock

Membeli bibit babi

loans.name: Goma Khan

texts.en:
Goma Khan lives in District 16 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He lives with his own family and is single. He works together with his brothers weaving carpets.

Goma Khan has good experience around his brothers. He wants to expand this business so he wants to take an individual loan to buy new machines to attract more clients and make good income to support his family. He is happy.

loans.use: To buy new machines for carpet weaving

loans.name: Ni Putu Warniasih

texts.id:
In a very traditional Balinese custom interpretation, women are often expected to stay at home to take care her children and her husband. That does not apply to Ni Putu Warniasih. She is a mother of three. Two of her three children are in elementary school. That condition creates the needs to cover school tuitions in addition to the living costs. One of her obsessions is to have the children to get the highest education possible so they can transform their life to be better than their parents. Although her husband is selling vegetables door to door, Ni Putu Warniasih does not want to sit around and do nothing. Utilizing a small lot in her yard, she and her husband made a small shed with three compartments. The first compartment is to grow the piglets, the second compartment is for the sow and the third compartment is for breastfeeding. With the loan from Dinari, Ni Putu Warniasih can buy a sow that will soon deliver the piglets which will then occupy the shed. She plan on harvesting every three months. She decides to do so to get a fast turn around to allow her to use the profit for additional capital and to help cover her family's living expense.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Arliadi Mahadi, Kiva Volunteer.

Di adat Bali kuno, seringkali muncul pemahaman bahwa wanita hanya diam dirumah untuk merawat anak dan melayani suami. Namun, hal itu tidak berlaku bagi Ni Putu Warniasih. Ni Putu Warniasih adalah ibu dengan 3 orang anak. Dua dari tiga anaknya sudah mengenyam pendidikan di bangku Sekolah dasar ( SD ). Kondisi seperti itu tentunya membutuhkan banyak biaya, baik untuk kebutuhan sehari – hari atau biaya sekolah. Satu keyakinan Ni Putu Warniasih adalah ia berkeinginan anaknya dapat menempuh pendidikan setinggi mungkin sehingga mereka akan dapat mengubah hidupnya menjadi lebih baik atau menjadi lebih baik dari orang tuanya. Walaupun suaminya berprofesi sebagi pedagang sayuran keliling, hal itu tidak membuat Ni Putu Warniasih berdiam diri saja. Dengan memanfaatkan sepetak tanah dibelakang rumahnya, Ni Putu Warniasih dengan suaminya membuat sebuah kandang dengan 3 ruangan. Ruangan pertama untuk anak babi yang digemukkan, ruang 2 untuk induk dan ruang 3 untuk induk yang menyusui. Dengan pinjaman dari Dinari, Ni Putu Warniasih membeli induk babi yang sudah dikawinkan. Perhitungannya induk babi itu akan segera melahirkan anak dan segera mengisi kandangnya. Ni Putu Warniasih berencana memelihara babi untuk babi guling yang dipanen 3 bulan sekali. Hal itu dipilihnya karena perputaran modalnya cepat, sehingga Ni Putu Warniasih bisa menyisihkan untuk modal dan kebutuhan sehari – hari. Dengan kegiatannya sekarang, Ni Putu Warniasih mampu membantu keuangan keluarganya.

loans.use: To purchase sows

loans.name: Ahammd Sadiq

texts.en:
Ahammd Sadiq lives in District 6 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is educated and married and has one son. He has a bodybuilding club; he is a master of bodybuilding.

Ahmmd Sadiq started bodybuilding 8 years ago when he was in Iran. When he came back in 2004, he opened a club in one of the densely populated places of Kabul.

Now he wants to expand his business so he wants to take an individual loan to buy one or two new machines so that he can find more clients and make his club more popular to make a good future for his family.

loans.use: To buy new machines
